text: so we're gonna come clean with you here
the only thing more nerve-wracking than
addressing 5,000 people who by the way
are in the rain is knowing that you are
sharing a stage with the likes of de
Nuria Saul Khan and who could forget the
one and only Casey Gerald's I think what
Sarah's trying to say is we know this
isn't exactly laughing weather but
please laugh at our jokes no seriously
my children are here and they still
think daddy's funny so please it truly
is an honor though to be standing here
before all of you today especially
because so many of you here are
responsible for the successes of our
student body to our families friends
partners and members of the HPS faculty
administration and staff we would like
to take a moment on behalf of our entire
student body to thank you from the
bottom of our hearts now it wouldn't be
a Jordan and Sarah speech without us
mentioning the fact that we're both from
New Mexico that's that's right against
all odds Sarah and I actually both hail
from the land of enchantment but as
Karen alluded to that's just about where
the surface level similarities ended she
mentioned Sarah spent the last couple
years before HBS in San Francisco and
Jordan spent a few years before HBS in
the very cosmopolitan town of Lubbock
Texas that's right I came to HBS with a
wife of five years and an 18 month old
son and all I brought with me was to
take two suitcases and a somewhat
neglected house plans but you know it's
interesting on the surface it seems
unlikely that Jordan and I would have
even been friends let alone choose to
spend the next year together working on
the Student Association but what really
brought us together was a shared
variants of the power of this very HBS
community yeah I'll be honest with you
coming into HBS I had no idea what to
expect I mean I had I had no clue now I
had seen the social network you know the
movie about the founding of facebook
across the river so I think I assume
that all HBS students would be kind of
these statuesque genetic perfections
like the Winklevoss twins and actually
my hunch proved to be pretty correct HBS
students aren't brilliant funny and
ridiculously good-looking but I'm not
sure I expected to learn all the things
that I would soon learn from them and
and not necessarily about the things you
might expect most of the lessons came
from from seemingly small things humble
deeds subtle decisions the sort of
things that don't necessarily leap off a
page and scream for attention but whose
impact is almost impossible to measure
I'll always remember the first time I
experienced this at HBS during the first
week of school my section learned that
one of our classmates was actually going
through a pretty complex surgery that
would cause him to miss the first
several days of classes and so when he
finally joined us he stood up and he
introduced himself and in his
introduction he told us that more than
half of our section who by the way at
the time were complete strangers had
emailed him wishing him a speedy
recovery offering to take notes even
asking if he was accepting visitors and
we're sure each of you has similar
stories about your time at HBS for me it
was the number of classmates who
volunteered their babysitting services
for our son cooper so that Brittany and
I could go on a date free babysitting
services by the way for you it might
have been the typical private equity or
finance ninja who volunteered hours and
hours and hours of their time coaching
you on how to construct a DCF valuation
in Excel or maybe maybe it was the
consultant who took time out of their
day to help you prep for your first case
interview
or maybe more importantly it was a
section mate who served as a shoulder to
lean on when you experience the personal
or family tragedy these are all perfect
examples of acts of selflessness that
will never generate headlines but that
tell you so much about a person and
about a community as we look at these
stories we actually learn something
about leadership that perhaps wasn't
always made explicit in our classes that
a leader is not always defined by the
actions and the accomplishments that
yield headlines it's not necessarily
about having a larger-than-life
personality or even necessarily about
setting forth an ambitious vision what
this community taught Jordan and I is
that leadership is more often found in
the small and actionable things that
people do with good hearts and with an
intention to serve others we frequently
found more inspiration in the acts of
service performed by our peers than we
did in the case protagonists we studied
what our classmates taught us is that
the most impactful leaders serve others
wholeheartedly often quietly without
pretense pride or any hope of
recognition and these are lessons that
were truly grateful to have learned
during our time at HBS because as a
class our greatest opportunities and our
greatest challenges are still yet to
come and as I was thinking about that i
was actually reminded of one of my
favorite musicians he's a guy named Ben
Rector and he's got a line in one of his
songs and it's simple but it's really
poignant he says life is not the
mountaintops it's the walking in between
and he's right life is about more than
just the mountaintops or the headline
worthy times but also about appreciating
the everyday moments the walking in
between and and I think in our culture
that's easier
said than done right because what does
someone do every time they're sitting on
that mountaintop they tweet about it
right they Instagram it yeah they post
it on Facebook they post it to some sort
of social media platform that I probably
haven't even heard about yet you know
the point is everybody loves to post a
picture of themselves with Sir Alex
Ferguson when he comes to an HBS
classroom or post on facebook when they
just got a brand new promotion but
nobody wants to post a picture on
Instagram at two in the morning when
they just change the dirty diaper or you
know when they're struggling in finance
or having a tough time finding a job no
of course not but the truth is that how
we respond to those moments how we
approach those moments is equally as
important this reality is particularly
relevant to our class in which headline
moments will be plenty look around you
we are surrounded by some of the most
talented individuals in our peer group
some will take companies public others
will hold elected office and others will
solve major world problems it's it's
amazing to look at our class and it is
going to be such a privilege to
celebrate these headlines including
today in our graduation from this
amazing institution but if we're going
to fulfill HBS's mission of being
leaders that make a difference in the
world will it be enough to focus only on
the headlines or rather should we
constantly be asking ourselves are we
being engaged fathers and mothers
husbands and wives are we staying active
in our communities and our we conducting
business honorably even when no one is
watching these issues don't always make
the best posts on social media but in
them lays the power to truly make a
difference not only in our own lives but
also in the lives of those around us so
class of 2014 as we gather here together
to celebrate our time at harvard
business school and our reentry into the
real world our hope
is that we would not chase the headlines
but that we would write our own stories
with a sense of sincerity and purpose
and passion that we wouldn't find our
identities solely in those mountain top
moments but in how we live our lives
while we're walking in between thank you
for a tremendous and life-altering two
years and here's to many more together
congratulations class of 2014
